title: Hello!
text:
Welcome to my website! My name is Carlo Davis and I am a Master’s student in the Geoinformatics program at CUNY Hunter College. In this site, you can find samples of the maps and data visualizations I have created. Hope you enjoy!
If you have any questions, feel free to email me at carloidavis@gmail.com.

title: Carlo Davis
text:
CUNY Hunter College | New York, NY
Master of Science in Geoinformatics | Ongoing
Bowdoin College | Brunswick, ME
B.A. in Government & Legal Studies | 2008 - 2012

title: Carlo Davis
text:
A few things about me:

I grew up in Colorado
I live in Brooklyn
I love movies
I have a crazy dog named Enzo

title: Data
text:
To represent open space in New York City, I used Parks Properties, a dataset of all property managed partially or solely by the New York City Department of Parks & Recreation (DPR). This dataset is available via the NYC Open Data portal and was current as of February 4, 2025. This dataset includes some properties that are not properly classified as public open space, so I filtered the dataset using SQL to exclude the following categories of DPR properties (as described in DPR’s Parks Properties dataset user guide):







Category
Description




Cemetery
Standalone facility


Strip
Narrow, linear grass or paved area border or marginal property found in conjunction with the arterial street system and having no recreation or park equipment.


Undeveloped
Vacant, unimproved area of land which does not constitute a natural area and has no recreation or park equipment. Parks temporarily closed for construction purposes are also listed here.


Managed Sites
Sites under the jurisdiction of NYCParks but that offer either no recreational amenities, are under the management of another agency/entity, or are under a concession agreement


Lot
Standalone parking area


Mall
A series of linear center or border divider(s) of extended length, existing in conjunction with the local street system



The geometry of New York City’s neighborhoods was derived from the New York City Department of City Planning’s 2020 Neighborhood Tabulation Areas dataset, which is also available in the NYC Open Data portal. The total population of each Neighborhood Tabulation Areas or NTA in the 2020 U.S. Census was derived using the Enrich tool in ESRI ArcGIS Pro. I excluded the city’s non-residential NTAs (those classified as forts, hospital, navy yard, rail yards, cemeteries, airports, parks, or Rikers Island).
